title: Libre
description: Libre is a sidechain that leverages a Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS) consensus mechanism. It currently features three tokens: PBTC, PUSDT, and LIBRE. BTC live on the Libre network is managed by an alternative consensus mechanism that is not directly affiliated with Libre.

riskAnalysis.title: Libre's two-way peg relies on a third party provider
riskAnalysis.content:
BTC users who deposit funds onto Libre do so via the pNetwork chain. This is an alternative consensus mechanism that is governed by the pNetwork token and governance. The signers for the pNetwork bitcoin multi-sig, custodying the funds backing pBTC, participate in a MPC protocol.

⚠️ The pNetwork bridge has historically seen two exploits occur. One of those exploits involved BTC-backed tokens.

riskAnalysis.title: Data availability requirement is satisfied by Libre's permissioned validator set. ⚠️ Critical risk as node software is not currently open source
riskAnalysis.content:
The data availability and storage requirement is satisfied by Libre validators. Proposedly, anyone will be able to participate as a validator once the mainnet node implementation is open-source.

⚠️ Critical risk as node software is not currently open source.

riskAnalysis.title: The Libre network is operated by a permissioned validator set. ⚠️ Critical risk as node software is not currently open source
riskAnalysis.content:
Libre validators are responsible for proposing and signing blocks to finalize Libre transactions. There are 21 validators that participate in block production. They are selected for a round based on their voting power. Validators that are not selected as a part of this round must wait in a candidate pool. Rounds last 126 seconds. If there are not a minimum of 10 active validators, block production would fail.

When selected, validators win the right to propose blocks for 6 seconds during a specific round. During this time frame they must produce 12 blocks.

⚠️Critical risk as node software is not currently open source.

riskAnalysis.title: No settlement guarantees provided by Bitcoin. ⚠️ Critical risk as node software is not currently open source
riskAnalysis.content:
Settlement guarantees are finalized by Libre’s validator set and not by Bitcoin consensus participants.

⚠️ Critical risk as node software is not currently open source.

content.title: Node software not open source
content.content: Due to Libre’s mainnet node software not being open source, we have given critical risk scores. These will be updated when Libre’s node software is open source.

content.title: Token delegating used to select validators
content.content: LIBRE token holders can use their voting power to select validators. Voting power is based on the amount of tokens someone has, and how long they’ve been staked. Currently, four accounts hold over 50% of the voting power.

content.title: Unilateral exits to Bitcoin not possible
content.content: Users cannot unilaterally from Libre. Users must trust alternative consensus mechanisms to withdrawal funds.

content.title: Libre does not leak MEV to Bitcoin
content.content: Libre does not leak MEV to the Bitcoin base layer. Users trust that Libre validators will not reorder their transactions to extract MEV.

content.title: An alternative token plays a role in network security
content.content: Libre relies on the LIBRE token for network security and operation.

content.title: No fees paid to Bitcoin miners
content.content: Libre does not contribute to Bitcoin’s security budget.

content.title: Users trust the operators of the pNetwork to process their withdrawals
content.content: When users withdraw funds from the Libre chain, they trust the operators of the Libre chain to include their withdrawal transaction in a block. They additionally trust the operators of the pNetwork to process their withdrawal and release their funds on the Bitcoin main chain.

content.title: EOSIO technology stack
content.content:
The Libre Chain is built on the EOSIO (commonly known as EOS) is a blockchain framework in the EOS ecosystem. These chains run on a delegated proof-of-stake consensus mechanism. Validators are required to acquire and stake tokens, or have tokens be delegated towards them by ecosystem participants.

In Libre, token holders delegate their tokens and validators’ probability on winning blocks is based on their delegated tokens’ weighted voting power. This power is determined by the amount of tokens and how long they’ve been staked.

In EOS blockchain designs, only the top 21 block producers by staking power are able to produce blocks.

⚠️ Our assumption is that Libre mainnet is running on the EOSIO framework. Only the testnet implementation is open-source.

content.title: Fast payments
content.content: The Libre blockchain offers faster payments with lower fees than the Bitcoin mainchain.

content.title: Stablecoin payments
content.content: The Libre blockchain offers stablecoin payments.

content.title: Node implementation is not open-source
content.content:
The node implementation for Libre is not open source.

Information related to the pNetwork bridge is open source.
